revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2015}} The '''Australian School of Petroleum''' is a centre for petroleum education, training and research at the [[University of Adelaide]] in [[South Australia]]. The school integrates teaching and research programs in the disciplines of petroleum [[geoscience]], [[Petroleum engineering|engineering]] and [[management]] and was formed in 2003. It is housed in the purpose-built Santos Petroleum Engineering Building on the University's [[North Terrace]] campus. As of 2015 the Head of the school is Steve Begg. Prior to his appointment at the university in 2002, he worked for 19 years in the oil and gas industry; for 13 of those for [[BP]].{{Cite web|url = http://www.adelaide.edu.au/directory/steve.begg|title = Professor Steve Begg|date = 2015-01-28|accessdate = 2015-02-09|website = The University of Adelaide - University Staff Directory|publisher = The University of Adelaide|last = |first = }} == History == The [[University of Adelaide]] established the National Centre for Petroleum Geology and Geophysics (NCPGG) on campus in 1986. The School of Petroleum Engineering and Management (SPEM) was also established in 2000.{{Cite web|url = http://www.asp.adelaide.edu.au/about/|title = Australian School of Petroleum - About - History|date = |accessdate = 2015-02-08|website = University of Adelaide|publisher = University of Adelaide|last = |first = }} The latter development was facilitated by a commitment to the University of AU $25 million made by oil and gas company, [[Santos Limited]] in 1999. At the time it was believed to be 'the largest single industry sponsorship ever given to a public university in Australia.'{{Cite web|url = http://www.adelaide.edu.au/news/news82.html|title = News & events - $25 million Santos sponsorship a major boost for industry|date = 1999-08-13|accessdate = 2015-02-08|website = University of Adelaide|publisher = |last = |first = }} On 1 August 2001, Professor Peter Behrenbruch was appointed as the first Head of SPEM. He had been previously employed as Chief Reservoir Engineer with [[BHP Billiton]], and a partnership between the school and his former employer soon followed.{{Cite web|url = http://www.adelaide.edu.au/news/news269.html|title = BHP Billiton announces $100,000 funding|date = 2001-09-07|accessdate = 2015-02-08|website = The University of Adelaide|publisher = The University of Adelaide|last = |first = }} In July 2003, the NCPGG and the SPEM merged to form the Australian School of Petroleum. == Partnerships == BHP Billiton became the first corporate partner to follow Santos' original commitment of AU $25 million. The multi-national resource company committed $100,000 to funding research at the school, to be dispensed across 2002 and 2003. During a visit in 2001, Keith Hunter from BHP Billiton said of the relationship:
"We are looking forward to employing graduates from the School in four years time... We have also asked Professor Behrenbruch to develop some in-house courses for engineers already employed in BHP Billiton."
The University's Vice-Chancellor Cliff Blake said of the school's relationship with corporate sponsors:
"The company (Santos Ltd) and the University intended the School to operate as a major resource for the benefit of the entire oil and gas industry."
== Scholarships and prizes == The school offers scholarships and presents prizes annually to undergraduate and postgraduate students. Scholarships include:{{Cite web|url = http://www.asp.adelaide.edu.au/scholarships/|title = Australian School of Petroleum - Scholarships|date = |accessdate = 2015-02-09|website = University of Adelaide|publisher = University of Adelaide|last = |first = }} * [[Santos Limited|Santos]] Scholarships (which include half, full and incentive scholarships) * John F Kennedy Memorial Scholarship * [[Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association|APPEA]] Oil and Gas Industry Engineering Scholarship for Indigenous Australians * [[Society of Petroleum Engineers]] Scholarship Sixteen prizes are awarded annually, fourteen of which are sponsored by industry partners. Sponsors include: [[Beach Energy]], Bear and Brook Consulting, [[BP]], [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron Australia]], [[ConocoPhillips]], [[ExxonMobil]], [[Origin Energy]], [[Santos Limited|Santos]], [[Shellac|Shell]] and [[Woodside Energy]]. == External links == * [http://www.asp.adelaide.edu.au/ Australian School of Petroleum] == References == {{University of Adelaide}} [[Category:University of Adelaide]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Petroleum engineering schools]]

The '''BM-40A reactor''' is the [[nuclear fission]] [[nuclear reactor|reactor]] used to power four of the seven boats of the [[Soviet Navy]]'s Project 705 Лира (Lira or [[Alfa class submarine|Alfa]] in NATO designation) fourth generation submarines. It is a [[liquid metal cooled reactor]] (LMR), using [[enriched uranium|highly enriched]] [[uranium-235]] fuel to produce [[megawatt|155 MWt]] of power.
It was developed by [[OKB Gidropress]] in cooperation with [[IPPE]].
''BM-40A'' has two steam circulation loops.
==See also==
* [[OK-550 reactor]]
==External links== * [http://www.fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ship/row/rus/705.htm Project 705 Lira Alfa class] at the [[Federation of American Scientists]] website. * [http://www.gidropress.podolsk.ru/en/projects/nuclear-submarines.php Lead-bismuth cooled reactor plants for nuclear submarines] at the Gidropress website.
[[Category:Soviet naval reactors]] [[Category:Liquid metal fast reactors]]

page.title: Committee on the Safety of Nuclear Installations

revision.text:
The '''Committee on the Safety of Nuclear Installations''' is a committee of the [[OECD]]/[[Nuclear Energy Agency|NEA]].
According to its web site (see below): :The mission of the Committee on the Safety of Nuclear Installations (CSNI) is to assist member countries in maintaining and further developing the scientific and technical knowledge base required to assess the safety of nuclear reactors and fuel cycle facilities. The Committee is made up of senior scientists and engineers, with broad responsibilities for safety technology and research programmes, and representatives from regulatory authorities.
==External links== *[http://www.nea.fr/html/nsd/csni/index.html] - CSNI overview
[[Category:Nuclear safety and security]] [[Category:Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]]

{{Other uses|Lucky Dragon (disambiguation){{!}}Lucky Dragon}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image | Ship image=Daigo Fukuryū Maru 01.JPG | Ship caption= ''Daigo Fukuryū Maru'' on display in Tokyo }} {{Infobox ship career | Hide header= | Ship country= Japan | Ship flag= {{shipboxflag|Japan|civil}} | Ship name=*''Daigo Fukuryu Maru'' *("Lucky Dragon No.5") | Ship namesake= | Ship owner= | Ship operator= | Ship registry= | Ship route= | Ship ordered= | Ship awarded= | Ship builder= | Ship original cost= | Ship yard number= | Ship way number= | Ship laid down= | Ship launched=1947 | Ship sponsor= | Ship christened= | Ship completed= | Ship in service= | Ship out of service= | Ship renamed= | Ship reclassified= | Ship refit= | Ship struck= | Ship reinstated= | Ship homeport= | Ship identification= | Ship status= [[Museum ship]] since 1976 | Ship notes= | Ship badge= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics | Hide header= | Header caption= | Ship class= | Ship type=Fishing boat | Ship tonnage= | Ship displacement={{Convert|140.86|t|LT|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} | Ship tons burthen= | Ship length= {{Convert|28.56|m|abbr=on}} | Ship beam={{Convert|5.9|m|abbr=on}} | Ship height= | Ship draught= | Ship depth= | Ship hold depth= | Ship decks= | Ship deck clearance= | Ship propulsion={{Convert|250|hp|0|abbr=on}} engine | Ship speed={{Convert|5|kn|lk=in}} | Ship range= | Ship endurance= | Ship capacity= | Ship crew=23 | Ship notes= }} |} {{nihongo|'''''Daigo Fukuryū Maru'''''|第五福龍丸||'''''F/V Lucky Dragon 5'''''}} was a Japanese [[tuna]] [[fishing boat]] with a crew of 23 men which was contaminated by [[nuclear fallout]] from the United States [[Castle Bravo]] [[thermonuclear weapon]] test at [[Bikini Atoll]] on March 1, 1954.
The crew suffered [[acute radiation syndrome]] (ARS) for a number of weeks after the Bravo test in March. During their [[acute radiation syndrome|ARS treatment]], the crew were inadvertently infected with [[hepatitis C]] through [[blood transfusions]].<ref name="mainichi.jp">{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/perspectives/news/20140517p2a00m0na005000c.html |title=As I See It: Gov't must delve deeper into radiation exposure from Bikini Atoll incident|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524051201/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/perspectives/news/20140517p2a00m0na005000c.html|archive-date=May 24, 2014 }}</ref> All recovered except for Aikichi Kuboyama, the boat's chief radioman, who died on September 23, 1954, from an underlying [[liver cirrhosis]] compounded by the secondary hepatitis C infection.<ref name="Rhodes1996">{{cite book|author=Richard Rhodes|title=Dark Sun: The Making of the Hydrogen Bomb|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f113iCcn87wC|date=6 August 1996|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-684-82414-7|page=542}}</ref> Kuboyama is considered the first victim of the [[Thermonuclear weapon|hydrogen bomb]] and of test shot Castle Bravo.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wagingpeace.org/castle-bravo-sixty-years-of-nuclear-pain/|title=Castle Bravo: Sixty Years of Nuclear Pain|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707174139/http://www.wagingpeace.org/castle-bravo-sixty-years-of-nuclear-pain/|archive-date=July 7, 2014}}</ref>
==Early days and final voyage== Built in March 1947 and launched from [[Koza, Wakayama]], the boat was originally named {{nihongo|'''''Dainana Kotoshiro Maru'''''|第七事代丸||''Kotoshiro Maru No. 7''}}. It was a [[bonito]] boat and moored in [[Misaki]] Fishing Harbor, [[Kanagawa Prefecture]]. It was later remodeled into a [[tuna fishing]] boat. In 1953, it moved to [[Yaizu, Shizuoka|Yaizu Port, Shizuoka Prefecture]], with a new name, ''Daigo Fukuryū Maru'', translated as ''Lucky Dragon No. 5'' or the ''Fifth Lucky Dragon''.
The ''Lucky Dragon No. 5'' took five ocean voyages, the last of which began on January 22, 1954, and ended on March 14 of that year. The crew set off to go fishing in the Midway Sea near [[Midway Atoll]], but when they lost most of their [[trawl net]]s to the sea, they altered their course southward near the [[Marshall Islands]] and encountered fallout from the Castle Bravo nuclear test at Bikini Atoll on March 1.<ref name="web.archive.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.pcf.city.hiroshima.jp/virtual/VirtualMuseum_e/exhibit_e/exh0503_e/exh05032_e.html |title=Lucky Dragon No. 5 special exhibit |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010232525/http://www.pcf.city.hiroshima.jp/virtual/VirtualMuseum_e/exhibit_e/exh0503_e/exh05032_e.html |archivedate=October 10, 2008 }}</ref>
A map of the varying location of the boat in the days leading up to and after the day of the explosion is available. On March 1, the map depicts the vessel very near to the border of the [[US Navy]] issued "danger zone notice" dated October 10, 1953.<ref name="web.archive.org"/> Following March 1, the vessel charted a practically straight [[geodesic]] course back to its home port of Yaizu, passing the same [[latitude]] as [[Wake Island]] between March 4 and 6 and arriving at Yaizu on March 14.<ref name="web.archive.org"/>
The source of the map,<ref name="web.archive.org"/> does not state how the map was created, that is, it does not state that the [[ship log|ship's log]] was consulted in the creation of the map, nor does it provide the [[navigator]]'s measurements with the [[compass]] and [[sextant]] of the period.<ref name="web.archive.org"/> The exact position of the ship on the day of the explosion is therefore uncertain. Contemporary references give a figure of "80 miles east of Bikini Atoll" without stating the method by which the distance was computed.<ref>[https://encrypted.google.com/books?id=opAklHndAy8C&pg=PA6&dq=%22fukuryu+maru%22+ash&hl=en&sa=X&ei=DJmTU_HpNaWL7Aau6YCQBw&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22fukuryu%20maru%22%20ash&f=false Structure shielding against fallout gamma rays from nuclear detonations By Lewis Van Clief Spencer, Arthur B. Chilton, Charles Eisenhauer, Center for Radiation Research, United States. National Bureau of Standards, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. pg 6]</ref><ref>Nasaizumi, Research in the effects and influences of the nuclear bomb test explosions, Volume 2 Japan. Committee for Compilation of Report on Research in the Effects of Radioactivity, Japan Society for the Promotion of Science, 1956 - History - page 1281 onwards of 1835 pages.</ref> According to a 1997 paper by Martha Smith-Norris, the ship was operating "14 miles" outside the 57,000 square mile "Danger Area", and it was not detected by [[radar]] or visual [[spotter plane]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |jstor=23612829 |title=Only as Dust in the Face of the Wind": An Analysis of the BRAVO Nuclear Incident in the Pacific, 1954 Martha Smith-Norris The Journal of American-East Asian Relations Vol. 6, No. 1 (SPRING 1997), pp. 1–34}}</ref>
==Events surrounding March 1, 1954== <!-- [[WP:NFCC]] violation: [[File:Castle Bravo fish contamination map.png|left|thumb|Map showing points (X) where contaminated fish were caught or where the sea was found to be excessively radioactive. '''B'''=original "danger zone" around Bikini announced by the U.S. government. '''W'''="danger zone" extended later. '''xF'''=estimated position of the ''Lucky Dragon'' fishing boat when fallout began to arrive at their location.<ref>S. Sevitt, "The Bombs," The Lancet, July 23, 1955, pp. 199–201.</ref> '''NE, EC, and SE''' are equatorial currents.]] --> [[File:Bravo fallout2.png|right|thumb|The ''Bravo'' fallout plume spread dangerous levels of radiation over an area over {{convert|100|mi|km}} long, including inhabited islands. The contour lines show the cumulative radiation dose in [[roentgens]] (R) for the first 96 hours after the test.<ref>http://www.nuclearweaponarchive.org/Usa/Tests/Castle.html</ref>]] [[File:Bikini Atoll Post BRAVO.png|right|thumb|The [[Bikini Atoll]]. The Bravo crater is on the North West end of the atoll. [[Castle Bravo|the device's firing crew]] were located on Enyu island, variously spelt as Eneu island as depicted in this map.]] [[File:Daigo Fukuryu Maru.jpg|thumb|right|Daigo Fukuryū Maru in early 1950s, shortly before the incident]] The ''Daigo Fukuryū Maru'' encountered the [[nuclear fallout|fallout]] from the U.S. Castle Bravo nuclear test at Bikini Atoll, near the [[Marshall Islands]], on March 1, 1954. When the test was held, the ''Daigo Fukuryū Maru'' was catching fish outside the danger zone that the U.S. government had declared in advance. However, the test was more than twice as powerful as predicted, and changes in weather patterns blew nuclear fallout, in the form of a fine ash, outside the danger zone.<ref name="brit">{{cite book |last1=Arnold |first1=Lorna |authorlink1=Lorna Arnold |last2=Smith |first2=Mark |year=2006 |title=[[Britain, Australia and the Bomb]] |publisher=Palgrave Press |page=77 |isbn=978-1-4039-2101-7 |oclc=76350829}}</ref> On that day, the sky in the west lit up like a sunset. Seven minutes later, the sound of the explosion arrived, with fallout reaching the ship two hours later.<ref name="select.nytimes.com">Leonard Engel, [https://www.nytimes.com/1958/02/23/archives/twentythree-fishermen-and-a-bomb-the-voyage-of-the-lucky-dragon-by.html "Twenty-Three Fishermen and a Bomb; The Voyage of the Lucky Dragon"], ''New York Times", February 23, 1958, p. BR1.</ref>{{better source|date=August 2014}} The fishermen attempted to escape from the area,{{citation needed|date = May 2013}} but they took time to retrieve fishing gear from the sea, exposing themselves to radioactive fallout for several hours.
The fallout – fine white flaky dust of [[calcinated]] Bikini Island [[coral]], which absorbed highly radioactive [[fission product]]s and [[neutron activation|neutron activated isotopes]] – fell on the ship for three hours.{{when|date=June 2014}}{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} The fishermen scooped it into bags with their bare hands. One fisherman, Matashichi Oishi, reported that he "took a lick" of the dust that fell on his ship, describing it as gritty but with no taste.<ref name="search.japantimes.co.jp">Hoffman, Michael, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fb20110828a1.html Forgotten atrocity of the atomic age]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', August 28, 2011, p. 11.</ref> The dust stuck to surfaces, bodies and hair; after the radiation sickness symptoms appeared,{{when|date=June 2014}} the fishermen called it {{nihongo|''shi no hai''|死の灰||'''death ash'''}}.
===Events between March 2–14=== {{Expand section|date=June 2014}} Feeling ill,{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}{{failed verification|date=June 2014}} the crew set sail to return to Yaizu on March 2, and arrived on March 14.<ref name="web.archive.org"/>
===Events after return to Yaizu port=== [[File:The crew of Daigo Fukuryu-maru.JPG|thumb|left|Medical professionals, before the era of [[whole body counting]], assessing the radioactivity of a bedridden crew member by using a [[geiger counter]] on 31 March 1954, focusing on the person's hair, which would have collected dusty fallout.]] [[File:Inspection of Atomic tunas.JPG|thumb|right|Inspection of [[tuna]] with a geiger counter before sale at a [[fishmonger]]'s on 31 March 1954]] Japanese biophysicist Yasushi Nishiwaki immediately traveled from [[Osaka]] to Yaizu to examine the crew and their boat. He quickly concluded that they had been exposed to radioactive fallout and wrote a letter to the chief of the US [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|Atomic Energy Commission]] (AEC) asking for more information on how to treat the crew. The crew members, suffering from nausea, headaches, burns, pain in the eyes, bleeding from the gums, and other symptoms, were diagnosed with [[acute radiation syndrome]] and admitted to two [[Tokyo]] hospitals. On September 23, chief radio operator Aikichi Kuboyama, 40, died—the first Japanese victim of a hydrogen bomb.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} He left these words: "I pray that I am the last victim of an atomic or hydrogen bomb."<ref name="brit" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/mail/ed20090301a2.html|title=The Japan Times|date=March 1, 2009|accessdate=March 23, 2010}}</ref>{{better source|date=June 2014}} The US did not respond to Nishiwaki's letter or to letters from other Japanese scientists requesting information and help,<ref>[[Kyodo News]], "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120111b1.html Scientist immediately sought details from U.S. on 1954 Bikini H-bomb test]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', January 11, 2012, p. 2. Nishiwaki's letter, as of January 2012, was on display at the [[National Atomic Testing Museum]] in Nevada.</ref> although the United States did dispatch two medical scientists to Japan to study the effects of fallout on the ship's crew and to assist their doctors.<ref name="books.google.com">{{cite book|author=Michael Schaller|title=Altered States: The United States and Japan since the Occupation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D1KFROHI6cUC&pg=PA72|year=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-802337-1|page=72}}</ref><ref name="Chasing Loose Nukes">{{cite book|author=Derek Duke|title=Chasing Loose Nukes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y8QGts0KLw0C&pg=PA9|publisher=Dungan Books|page=9}}</ref> [[File:The head of the crew of Daigo Fukuryu-maru.JPG|thumb|left|The bald head of one of the crew on 7 April 1954, focusing on the burn and general skin discoloration]] [[File:Kuboyama Aikichi.JPG|thumb|left|Kuboyama Aikichi on 15 September 1954. Aikichi died on 23 September.]] [[File:Bereaved family of Kuboyama.JPG|thumb|left|Aikichi's grieving family]] The US government refused to disclose the fallout's composition due to "national security", as the fallout's isotopic ratios—namely a percentage of [[uranium-237]]—could reveal the design of the Castle Bravo device through [[nuclear forensics|radio-chemical analysis]], with this information having a history of being regarded as potentially revealing the means by which megaton yield nuclear devices achieve their yield.<ref>[https://www.princeton.edu/sgs/publications/sgs/pdf/2_4DeGeer.pdf The Radioactive Signature of the Hydrogen Bomb].</ref> For instance, [[Joseph Rotblat]] may have deduced the [[Teller-Ulam design|staging nature]] of the device by studying the ratio and presence of tell-tale isotopes present in the fallout.<ref>{{cite book|author=Reiner Braun|title=Joseph Rotblat: Visionary for Peace|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AGlav1OGtikC&pg=PA188|year=2007|publisher=Wiley|isbn=978-3-527-40690-6|page=188}}</ref> As of 1954, the [[Soviet Union]] had [[Soviet atomic bomb project|not yet been successful with thermonuclear staging]] and such information could have assisted in their development of a thermonuclear weapon. [[Lewis Strauss]], the head of the AEC, issued a series of denials; he also hypothesized that the lesions on the fishermen's bodies were not caused by radiation but by the chemical action of the caustic [[burnt lime]] that is produced when coral is calcined, that they were inside the danger zone. He told [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|President Eisenhower's]] press secretary that the ''Lucky Dragon #5'' may have been a "red spy outfit", commanded by a Soviet agent intentionally exposing the ship's crew and catch to embarrass the USA and gain intelligence on the test's device.<ref>Schreiber, Mark, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/fl20120318x1.html Lucky Dragon's lethal catch]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', March 18, 2012, p. 7.</ref>
Later, the United States expanded the danger zone and it was revealed that in addition to the ''Daigo Fukuryū Maru'', many other fishing boats were in the expanded zone at the time. It is estimated that about one hundred fishing boats were contaminated to some degree by fallout from the test.<ref name="titus" /> Despite denials by Lewis Strauss concerning the extent of the claimed contamination of the fish caught by ''Daigo Fukuryu Maru'' and other ships, the [[Food and Drug Administration|FDA]] later imposed rigid restrictions on tuna imports.<ref name="titus">{{cite book|author=A. Costandina Titus|title=Bombs in the Backyard: Atomic Testing and American Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eQfG-U5iAPYC&pg=PA49|year=2001|publisher=University of Nevada Press|isbn=978-0-87417-370-3|page=49}}</ref>
At first, the US claimed that the extent of the ''Lucky Dragon'' incident contamination was trivial.<ref name="Mahaffey2014">{{cite book|author=James Mahaffey|title=Atomic Accidents: A History of Nuclear Meltdowns and Disasters: From the Ozark Mountains to Fukushima|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cuiZAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT106|date=4 February 2014|publisher=Pegasus Books|isbn=978-1-4804-4774-5|page=105}}</ref> Later, the United States paid Kuboyama's widow and children the equivalent in yen of about $2,800 (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|2800|1954|r=-2}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}}).<ref name= Mahaffey2014/> The tragedy of the ''Daigo Fukuryū Maru'' gave rise to a fierce [[anti-nuclear movement]] in Japan, rising especially from the fear that the contaminated fish had entered the market.<ref name="MooneyLanza2013">{{cite book|author1=Jadwiga E. Pieper Mooney|author2=Fabio Lanza|title=De-Centering Cold War History: Local and Global Change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dYKN7GnhruEC&pg=PA29|date=25 January 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-18407-9|page=21}}</ref> The Japanese and U.S. governments negotiated a compensation settlement, with the transfer to Japan of a compensation of $15,300,000,<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20110719155737/http://www.brookings.edu/projects/archive/nucweapons/50.aspx 50 Facts About U.S. Nuclear Weapons. Atomic Audit: The Costs and Consequences of U.S. Nuclear Weapons Since 1940. Brookings Institution. "Money paid by the State Department to Japan following fallout from the 1954 "Bravo" test: $15,300,000"</ref> of which the fishery received a compensation of $2 million, with the surviving crew receiving about [[¥]] 2 million each,<ref name="chugoku">{{cite web|date = February 29, 2004|url = http://www.chugoku-np.co.jp/abom/04e/kyodo/Ak04022901.html|title = Bikini Atoll H-bomb damaged fisheries, created prejudice|publisher = chugoku|accessdate = November 30, 2008|last = Keiji Hirano|quote = |deadurl = bot: unknown|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130302101239/http://www.chugoku-np.co.jp/abom/04e/kyodo/Ak04022901.html|archivedate = March 2, 2013|df = mdy-all}}</ref> ($5,550 in 1954, ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|5550|1954|r=-2}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}}<ref name="inflation">In April 25, 1949 the US dollar was pegged to the YEN at [[Japanese yen#Historical exchange rate|$USD 1 = 360 YEN]]</ref>). It was also agreed that the victims would not be given ''[[hibakusha]]'' status.<ref name="chugoku"/> The Japanese government pledged that it would not pursue further reparations from the U.S. government.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}}
==Medical symptoms and treatment== {{Expand section|date=June 2014}} The majority of medical experts believe that the crew members were infected with [[hepatitis C]] through [[blood transfusions]] during part of their [[acute radiation syndrome]] treatment.<ref name="mainichi.jp"/>
The longest staying crew member spent about a year in hospital following their return to port.<ref name="manchester.ac.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.manchester.ac.uk/discover/news/article/?id=7230 |title=Japan nuclear victims in 1950s ‘guinea pigs’ and 'Communists' 12 Jul 2011. Citing Dr Aya Homei ‘Nuclear Japan and the Effects of Radiation, 1945–1960’ journal, Historical Studies in the Natural Sciences.}}</ref>
==Health history of crew== {{Expand section|date=June 2014}} Like the [[hibakusha]], survivors of atomic bombings in Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945, the Lucky Dragon crew were stigmatized because of the Japanese public’s [[radiophobia|irrational fear of those exposed to radiation]] (it was commonly believed to be contagious). The crew tried to stay quiet about their exposure for a number of decades, beginning with their discharge from hospital. A number of the crew also had to move away from their previous places of residence to make a fresh start.<ref name="manchester.ac.uk"/>
Former crew members include the 87-year-old, as of 2014, Susumu Misaki, who opened a tofu shop after the incident.<ref name="mainichi.jp"/>
Twenty years old at the time, Matashichi Oishi, who is reported to have licked the mysterious fallout substance which fell on his ship in March 1954, as a taste test to ascertain its properties,<ref name="search.japantimes.co.jp"/> was 79 years old in August 2013. After the exposure, he left his hometown to open a dry cleaning business. Beginning in the 1980s, he frequently gave talks advocating [[nuclear disarmament]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/08/06/national/victim-of-bikini-atoll-h-bomb-fallout-keeps-the-faith/#.U5K9nldkb0s |title=Victim of Bikini Atoll H-bomb fallout keeps the faith}}</ref> In 2011, he published a book titled, "The Day the Sun Rose in the West: The Lucky Dragon and I."
==Radioactivity of the ship post contamination== {{Expand section|date=June 2014}} [[File:Daigo Fukuryū Maru 02.JPG|thumb|right|The ship in its museum in 2007]] The ''Daigo Fukuryū Maru'' was deemed safe for public viewing and was preserved in 1976. It is now on display in Tokyo at the Tokyo Metropolitan Daigo Fukuryū Maru Exhibition Hall.<ref>[http://d5f.org/ 都立 第五福竜丸展示館 Official Site<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.hiroshimapeacemedia.jp/mediacenter_d/w_museum/20090130142323620_en.html The Tokyo Metropolitan Daigo Fukuryu Maru Exhibition Hall]</ref>
==Media== The Toho Film ''Gojira'' (''[[Godzilla (1954 film)|Godzilla]]'', 1954), was inspired in part by this event. The ship itself appears on a poster in 2001's ''Godzilla, Mothra, King Ghidorah: Giant Monsters All-Out Attack'', which also features Godzilla coming ashore and wreaking havoc in the Yaizu area.
A poem, ''Japon Balıkçısı'' (The Japanese Fishermen), was written in 1956 by Turkish poet [[Nâzım Hikmet Ran]] about the events.<ref>http://www.siir.gen.tr/siir/n/nazim_hikmet/the_japanese_fisherman.htm</ref>
[[Ralph Lapp]] wrote ''[[The Voyage of the Lucky Dragon]]'', which was published in 1958.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ralph E. Lapp|title=The Voyage of the Lucky Dragon|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VeuJHmVUWxAC|year=1958|asin=B0000CJZ45}}</ref> It was reviewed on the front page of ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]''.<ref name="select.nytimes.com"/>
A film version of the events, [[Lucky Dragon No. 5 (film)|''Daigo Fukuryū Maru'']] (1959), was directed and screenwritten by [[Kaneto Shindo]], and produced by [[Kindai Eiga Kyokai]] and ''Shin Seiki Eiga''.
==See also== *[[History of nuclear weapons]] *[[Katsuko Saruhashi]] – studied the transport of fallout in the ocean, and thus determined the ocean’s circulation patterns, after the 1954 Castle Bravo explosion *{{USS|Patapsco|AOG-1|6}}, [[US Navy]] tanker also contaminated by fallout from Castle Bravo while at sea *[[Project 4.1]] — study of other victims of Bravo contamination *[[Anti-nuclear movement]] *[[History of the anti-nuclear movement]] *''[[Godzilla (1954 film)]]'' *''[[The Plutonium Files]]''
===[[Nuclear incident]]s involving Japan=== *[[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]] (1945) *[[Mutsu (nuclear ship)|''Mutsu'' (nuclear ship)]] (1974) *[[Tokaimura nuclear accident]] (1997, 1999) *[[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] ([[Okuma, Fukushima|Okuma]], 2011)

{{Infobox film | name = Damnation | image = DAMNATION poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Official poster | director = {{Plain list | * Travis Rummel * Ben Knight }} | producer = {{Plain list | * Matt Stoecker * Travis Rummel }} <ref>http://www.dcenvironmentalfilmfest.org/films/show/1154</ref> | writer = | narrator = | music = | cinematography = {{Plain list | * Ben Knight * Travis Rummel * Matt Stoecker }} | editing = Ben Knight | studio = <!-- or: | production companies = --> | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2014|03|10|SXSW}} | runtime = | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = <!-- Please use condensed and rounded values, e.g. "£11.6 million" not "£11,586,221" --> }}
'''''DamNation''''' is a 2014 advocacy [[documentary film]] about the changing attitudes in the [[United States]] concerning the large [[List of dams and reservoirs in United States|system]] of [[dams]] in the country. <!-- Running time is given variously as 87 and 94 minutes. -->
The film was released on March 10, 2014. Blu-ray and DVD versions were also released in 2014.<ref>http://damnationfilm.com/</ref>
The film takes an explicit point of view in support of the emerging [[Environmentalism|environmental]] strategy of [[dam removal]] as a way to restore river [[ecosystem]]s.
==Awards== * "Documentary Spotlight" (audience award) at [[South by Southwest]] (SXSW Film Festival), 2014 <ref>http://sxsw.com/film/awards/winners-2014</ref> * Winner, 2014 "Documentary Award for Environmental Advocacy," Environmental Film Festival in the Nation's Capital.<ref>http://www.dcenvironmentalfilmfest.org/films/show/1154</ref>
==References== <references/>

{{other people|David Pearce}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use British English|date=August 2016}} '''David W. Pearce''' [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (11 October 1941 – 8 September 2005) was [[Professor|Emeritus Professor]] at the Department of Economics at [[University College London]] (UCL). He specialised in, and was a pioneer of, [[environmental economics]], having published over fifty books and over 300 academic articles on the subject, including his 'Blueprint for a Green Economy' series.
==Background== David Pearce was born in [[Harrow, London]] on 11 October 1941, and attended Harrow Weald county grammar school, now part of [[Harrow College]]. He graduated in [[Politics, Philosophy, and Economics]] from [[Lincoln College, Oxford]] in 1963 (1st class) and then studied economics at [[London School of Economics]] from 1963 to 1964. He held academic posts at the Universities of [[Lancaster University|Lancaster]], [[University of Southampton|Southampton]], Leicester (from 1974-1979), and Aberdeen (Chair in political economy until 1983) before arriving at UCL as Professor of Political Economy and later in Economics in 1983, retiring in 2004.
During his career he was the chief environmental adviser to the UK Secretaries of State between 1989 and 1992—[[Christopher Patten]] and [[Michael Heseltine]]. He also provided advice to a number of major companies. He was a convening lead author of the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]].
He was co-director of the environmental economics research centre, [[CSERGE]] (Centre for Social and Economic Research on the Global Environment), from 1991 to 2001. Pearce also established the internationally renowned [[Master's degree|MSc]] in Environmental and Resource Economics at UCL. He was an inspirational teacher held in the highest esteem by the many graduates of this degree, most of whom are now working in environmental policy making and research throughout the world.
Pearce married Sue in 1966 and had two sons, Daniel and Corin. He lived latterly in Saffron Walden, Essex.
==Scholarship== Pearce is best known for setting out economic valuation techniques for natural phenomena, arguing that the environment is "under-priced" and that environmental services may be calculated.<ref>https://www.ucl.ac.uk/news/news-articles/0509/05092101</ref> If they are, their true worth is more likely to be recognised. His early work was on cost-benefit analysis and the economics of pollution and natural resource depletion, before these ideas entered the mainstream of the economic sciences and policymaking. ''Blueprint for Green Economy'' was published in 1989 (with Anil Markandya and Ed Barbier), and was a bestselling work with strong influence on governments in Britain and beyond. It advocated basing policy on the criterion of "sustainability", valuing environmental effects, and making use of market incentives. Market-based policies such as pollution taxes, tradable permits and conservation payments have some of their origins in Pearce's work—for example, Britain's landfill tax, the EU's emissions trading scheme and the various mechanisms for international pollution offsets in the [[Kyoto Protocol]].
For Pearce, [[sustainability]] involved each generation passing on at least as much capital as it inherited. Environmental capital describes the stock and the state of natural resources. Economic damage was inevitable but could be controlled through realistic valuation in the market; the price of precious resources, or penalties for damaging them, should be set high (e.g. for noise, waste, global warming, risks to life and health, species conservation and biodiversity).<ref name="GuardianObit">{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2005/sep/22/highereducation.guardianobituaries | title=Obituary: David Pearce | publisher=TheGuardian.com | first=Stephen | last=Smith | date=21 September 2005 | accessdate=2 December 2016}}</ref> Without this, future generations would suffer.
His love for nature and his care for the environment resonate through his work. At the same time, he was fiercely critical of environmental alarmism and sloppy environmental policy.<ref>D.W. Pearce (2006), [[Energy Economics (journal)|Energy Economics]], 28: 149-158</ref>{{editorializing|date=December 2012}}. The "valuation" of natural phenomena was widely debated and challenged, sometimes by critics who saw Pearce as a supporter of market-based, neoliberal economic policy.<ref name="GuardianObit" />
Pearce was commissioned by the [[Construction Research and Innovation Strategy Panel]] to write a report about the construction industry <ref> Pearce, D. (2003) ''The social and economic value of construction'' pub. New Construction Industry Research and Innovation Strategy Panel</ref> and after his death, a special issue of the journal Building Research & Information was dedicated to his memory in 2006.
==Honours== *[[Global 500 Roll of Honour]] for Services to the World Environment by the [[United Nations Environment Programme]] (1989) *[[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (Officer, Order of the British Empire) (2000) *'Lifetime Achievement Award', [[European Association of Environmental and Resource Economists (EAERE)]] (2004)for contributions to the development of environmental economics in Europe. *EAERE inaugurated [http://www.eaere.org/content/david-pearce-lectures a series of lectures] in his honour with the objective of giving a prominent space within our conferences to the presentation of high quality work on the application of environmental economics to real policy making (2009).
==Death== David Pearce died of [[leukaemia]] in September 2005, at the age of 63, only hours after being diagnosed.
==References== *[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U30361 PEARCE, Prof. David William], ''Who Was Who'', A & C Black, 1920–2015; online edn, Oxford University Press, 2014 {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.theguardian.com/life/science/story/0,12996,1575239,00.html The Guardian obituary] *{{cite news |date=17 September 2005 |title=Professor David Pearce - Obituaries |work=[[The Independent]] |author=Barrett, S. |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/professor-david-pearce-507164.html |accessdate=2009-08-04}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060117055725/http://www.ucl.ac.uk/news/news-articles/05092101 University College London obituary] *{{cite web |year=2005 |title=CSERGE Working Paper PA 05-01: The ‘Blueprint’ Legacy - a review of Professor David Pearce’s contribution to environmental economics and policy |publisher=CSERGE website, [[University of East Anglia]] |author=Turner, K. |url=http://www.uea.ac.uk/env/cserge/pub/wp/pa/pa_2005_01.htm |accessdate=2009-08-04}} *[http://www.eaere.org/content/david-pearce-lectures EAERE citation] - David's 'Lifetime Achievement Award' from the European Association of Environmental and Resource Economists *[http://ideas.repec.org/e/ppe198.html IDEAS/RePEc] *[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=david+pearce+environment&btnG=Search Google Scholar]
{{Authority control}}

The '''drift velocity''' is the [[average velocity]] that a particle, such as an [[electron]], attains in a material due to an [[electric field]]. It can also be referred to as axial drift velocity. In general, an electron will propagate randomly in a [[Electrical conductor|conductor]] at the [[Fermi velocity]]. An applied electric field will give this random motion a small net flow velocity in one direction.
In a [[semiconductor]], the two main carrier scattering mechanisms are [[ionized impurity scattering]] and [[lattice scattering]].
Because current is proportional to drift velocity, which in a resistive material is, in turn, proportional to the magnitude of an external electric field, [[Ohm's law]] can be explained in terms of drift velocity.
The most elementary expression of [[Ohm's law]] is:
:<math> u= \mu E ,</math>
where {{math|''u''}} is the drift velocity, {{math|''μ''}} is the [[electron mobility]] (with units m<sup>2</sup>/([[volt|V]]⋅s)) of the material and {{math|''E''}} is the [[electric field]] (with units V/m).
==Experimental measure== The formula for evaluating the drift velocity of charge carriers in a material of constant [[cross-section (geometry)|cross-section]]al area is given by:<ref>{{cite book|last=Griffiths|first=David|title=Introduction to Electrodynamics|year=1999|publisher=Prentice-Hall|location=Upper Saddle River, NJ|page=289|edition=3}}</ref>
:<math>u = {j \over n q} ,</math>
where {{math|''u''}} is the drift velocity of electrons, {{math|''j''}} is the [[current density]] flowing through the material, {{math|''n''}} is the charge-carrier [[number density]], and {{math|''q''}} is the [[electric charge|charge]] on the charge-carrier.
This can also be written as:
:<math>j = nqu</math>
But the current density and drift velocity, j and u, are in fact vectors, so this relationship is often written as:
:<math>\mathbf{J} = \rho \mathbf{u} \,</math>
where
:<math>\rho = nq </math>
is the [[charge density]] (SI unit: coulombs per [[cubic metre]]).
In terms of the basic properties of the right-[[cylindrical]] [[electrical current|current]]-carrying [[metal]]lic [[electrical conductor|ohmic conductor]], where the charge-carriers are [[electrons]], this expression can be rewritten as {{Citation needed|date=June 2013}}:
:<math>u = {m \; \sigma \Delta V \over \rho e f \ell} ,</math>
where *{{math|''u''}} is again the drift velocity of the electrons, in [[metre|m]]⋅[[second|s]]<sup>−1</sup> *{{math|''m''}} is the [[molecular mass]] of the metal, in [[kg]] *{{math|''σ''}} is the [[electric conductivity]] of the medium at the temperature considered, in [[siemens (unit)|S]]/[[metre|m]]. *{{math|Δ''V''}} is the [[voltage]] applied across the conductor, in [[volt|V]] *{{math|''ρ''}} is the [[density]] ([[mass]] per unit [[volume]]) of the conductor, in [[kg]]⋅[[metre|m]]<sup>−3</sup> *{{math|''e''}} is the [[elementary charge]], in [[coulomb (unit)|C]] *{{math|''f''}} is the number of [[electron|free electrons]] per [[atom]] *{{math|''ℓ''}} is the [[length]] of the conductor, in [[metre|m]]
== Numerical example == Electricity is most commonly conducted in a copper wire. [[Copper]] has a density of {{val|8.94|u=g/cm<sup>3</sup>}}, and an [[atomic weight]] of {{val|63.546|u=g/mol}}, so there are {{val|140685.5|u=mol/m<sup>3</sup>}}. In one [[Mole (unit)|mole]] of any element there are {{val|6.02|e=23}} atoms ([[Avogadro's constant]]). Therefore, in {{val|1|u=m<sup>3</sup>}} of copper there are about {{val|8.5|e=28}} atoms ({{nowrap|{{val|6.02|e=23}} × {{val|140685.5|u=mol/m<sup>3</sup>}}}}). Copper has one free electron per atom, so {{math|''n''}} is equal to {{val|8.5|e=28}} electrons per cubic metre.
Assume a current {{nowrap|1={{math|''I''}} = 1 ampere}}, and a wire of {{val|2|u=mm}} diameter (radius = {{val|0.001|u=m}}). This wire has a cross sectional area of {{val|3.14|e=-6|u=m<sup>2</sup>}} ({{nowrap|1={{math|''A''}} = π × ({{val|0.001|u=m}})<sup>2</sup>}}). The charge of one [[electron]] is {{nowrap|1={{math|''q''}} = {{val|-1.6|e=-19|u=C}}}}. The drift velocity therefore can be calculated:
:<math>\begin{align} u &= {I \over nAq}\\ u &= \frac{1 \text{C}/\text{s}}{\left(8.5 \times 10^{28} \text{m}^{-3}\right) \left(3.14 \times 10^{-6} \text{m}^2\right) \left(1.6 \times 10^{-19} \text{C}\right)}\\ u &= 2.3 \times 10^{-5} \text{m}/\text{s} \end{align}</math>
Dimensional analysis:
<math> u = \dfrac{\text{A}}{\dfrac{\text{electron}}{\text{m}^3}{\cdot}\text{m}^2\cdot\dfrac{\text{C}}{\text{electron}}} = \dfrac{\dfrac{\text{C}}{\text{s}}}{\dfrac{1}{\text{m}}{\cdot}\text{C}} = \dfrac{\text{m}}{\text{s}} </math>
Therefore, in this wire the electrons are flowing at the rate of {{val|23|u=μm/s}}. At 60 Hz alternating current, this means that within half a cycle the electrons drift less than 0.2 μm. In other words, electrons flowing across the contact point in a switch will never actually leave the switch.
By comparison, the Fermi flow velocity of these electrons (which, at room temperature, can be thought of as their approximate velocity in the absence of electric current) is around {{val|1570|u=km/s}}.<ref>http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/electric/ohmmic.html Ohm's Law, Microscopic View, retrieved 2015-11-16</ref>
==See also== *[[Flow velocity]] *[[Electron mobility]] *[[Speed of electricity]] *[[Drift chamber]] *[[Guiding center]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/electric/ohmmic.html Ohm's Law: Microscopic View] at Hyperphysics
{{DEFAULTSORT:Drift Velocity}} [[Category:Condensed matter physics]]

{{rewrite|date=July 2018}}
'''[[Endothermic]] gas''' is a gas that inhibits or reverses [[oxidation]] on the surfaces it is in contact with. This gas is the product of incomplete [[combustion]] in a controlled environment. An example is [[hydrogen gas]] (H<sub>2</sub>), [[nitrogen gas]] (N<sub>2</sub>), and [[carbon monoxide]] (CO). The hydrogen and carbon monoxide are [[reducing agent|reducing agents]], so they work together to shield surfaces from oxidation.
Endothermic gas is often used as a carrier gas for gas [[carburizing]] and [[carbonitriding]]. An endothermic gas generator could be used to supply heat to form an [[endothermic reaction]].<ref name=Herring>{{cite web|last1=Herring|first1=Daniel H.|title=Principles and Use of Endothermic Gas Generators|url=http://heat-treat-doctor.com/documents/Endothermic%20Gas%20Generators.pdf|website=heat-treat-doctor|accessdate=28 May 2018}}</ref>
Synthesised in the catalytic retort(s) of endothermic generators, the gas in the endothermic atmosphere is combined with an additive gas including [[natural gas]], [[Propane|propane ]] (C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub>) or air and is then used to improve the surface chemistry work positioned in the furnace.<ref name=berry>{{cite web|last1=Berry|first1=Theodore P.|title=AN OVERVIEW OF ENDOTHERMIC GENERATORS|url=http://www.mcgoff-bethune.com/furnace/endo.pdf|website=mcgoff-bethune|accessdate=28 May 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Endothermic Gas Generator Diagram.jpeg|thumb|Endothermic Gas Generator Diagram]]
There are '''two''' common purposes<ref name=Herring></ref> of the atmospheres in the heat treating industry: # Protect the processed material from surface reactions (chemically inert) # Allow surface of processed material to change (chemically reactive)
'''Principal Components''' of Endothermic Gas Generators <ref name=berry></ref>: # '''Heating Chamber''' for supplying heat by electric heating elements of [[combustion]], # Vertical '''cylindrical retorts''', # Tiny, porous '''ceramic''' pieces that are saturated with [[nickel]], which acts as a [[catalyst]] for the reaction, # '''Cooling heat exchanger''' in order to cool the products of the reaction as quickly as possible so that it reaches a particular temperature which stops any further reaction, # '''Control system''' which will help maintain the consistency of the temperature of the reaction which will help adjust the gas ratio, providing the wanted dew point.
'''Chemistry''' of Endothermic Gas Generators<ref name=Herring></ref>: * N<sub>2</sub> ([[Nitrogen]]) → 45.1% (volume) * CO ([[Carbon Monoxide]]) → 19.6% (volume) * CO<sub>2</sub> ([[Carbon Dioxide]]) → 0.4% (volume) * H<sub>2</sub> ([[Hydrogen]]) → 34.6% (volume) * CH<sub>4</sub> ([[Methane]]) → 0.3% (volume) * [[Dew Point]] → +20/+50 * Gas Ratio → 2:6:1
'''Applications''' of Endothermic Gas Generators<ref name=Herring></ref>: # Annealing: Iron and Steel # [[Brazing]]: Copper and Silver # Carbon Restoration: Carburizing, Carbonitriding, Nitrocarburizing # Neutral Hardening: Low, medium and high alloy carbon steels # Normalizing: Iron and Steel # Sintering: Powder Metals
It is relatively simple to operate and maintain endothermic gas generators, however, maintenance such as the burnout process is often overlooked.<ref name=Pye>{{cite web|last1=Pye|first1=David|title=Heat Treating Process|url=https://www.asminternational.org/documents/10192/1914052/htp00207p037.pdf/d711c8f7-b88a-4dd2-965a-24ed4b9b474a/HTP00207P037|accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref>
'''Troubleshooting''' the Endothermic Gas Generator (Cracking at 1040°C)<ref name=Pye></ref>: * When the due point is high and the carbon potential is low, it often leads to an air leak. This should be prevented by checking seals, joints as well as flanges. One should also check the retort for leakage. Checking the compressor by checking the position and location of the sample point is also ideal to prevent air leakage. * When the due point is low and the carbon potential is high, one should check the catalyst in retort (Burnout). The cooler on discharge should also be checked along with piping to furnace.
== See also == * [[Forming gas]]
== References == <references />
{{physical-chemistry-stub}}
[[Category:Gases]] [[Category:Industrial gases]]

[[Image:Hailwood-Horrobin EMC graph.svg|thumb|300px|Equilibrium moisture content of wood versus humidity and temperature, according to the Hailwood-Horrobin equation.]]
The '''equilibrium moisture content''' ('''EMC''') of a [[hygroscopic]] material surrounded at least partially by air is the [[moisture content]] at which the material is neither gaining nor losing moisture. The value of the EMC depends on the material and the [[relative humidity]] and [[temperature]] of the air with which it is in contact. The speed with which it is approached depends on the properties of the material, the [[surface-area-to-volume ratio]] of its shape, and the speed with which humidity is carried away or towards the material (e.g. [[diffusion]] in stagnant air or [[convection]] in moving air).
== Equilibrium moisture content of grains ==
The moisture content of grains is an essential property in food storage. The moisture content that is safe for long-term storage is 12% for corn, sorghum, rice and wheat and 11% for soybean<ref name="sadakam">Sadakam, Samy Grain Drying Tools: Equilibrium Moisture Content Tables and Psychrometric Charts. Univ. Arkansas, FSA1074</ref>
At a constant relative humidity of air, the EMC will drop by about 0.5% for every increase of 10 °C air temperature.<ref name="FAO2011">FAO. 2011. Rural structures in the tropics. Design and development. Chapter 16: Grain crop drying, handling, and storage. Rome. http://www.fao.org/docrep/015/i2433e/i2433e10.pdf</ref>
The following table shows the equilibriums for a number of grains (data from <ref name="sadakam" />). These values are only approximations since the exact values depend on the specific variety of a grain.<ref name="FAO2011" />
{| class="wikitable" ! ! ! colspan="4" |'''Corn kernels''' ! colspan="4" |'''Soybean''' ! colspan="4" |'''Sorghum''' ! colspan="4" |'''Long Grain Rice''' ! colspan="4" |'''Durum Wheat''' |- ! | style="text-align:right;" |'''[[Celsius|°C]]''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''1.7''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''10.0''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''21.1''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''37.8''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''1.7''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''10.0''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''21.1''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''37.8''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''1.7''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''10.0''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''21.1''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''37.8''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''1.7''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''10.0''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''21.1''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''37.8''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''1.7''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''10.0''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''21.1''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''37.8''' |- !'''[[Relative humidity|RH]]''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''''[[Fahrenheit|°F]]''''' | style="text-align:right;" |'''''35''''' | == Equilibrium moisture content of wood ==
The [[moisture]] content of wood below the [[fibre saturation point|fiber saturation point]] is a function of both [[relative humidity]] and [[temperature]] of surrounding air. The moisture content (''M'') of wood is defined as:
:<math>M = \frac{m-m_{od}}{m_{od}}</math>
where ''m'' is the mass of the wood (with moisture) and <math>m_{od}</math> is the oven-dry mass of wood (i.e. no moisture).<ref>What is Equilibrium Moisture Content? http://www.wagnermeters.com/wood-moisture-meter/moisture-content-and-equilibrium-determined-by-relative-humidity/</ref> If the wood is placed in an environment at a particular temperature and relative humidity, its moisture content will generally begin to change in time, until it is finally in equilibrium with its surroundings, and the moisture content no longer changes in time. This moisture content is the EMC of the wood for that temperature and relative humidity.
The '''Hailwood-Horrobin equation''' for two hydrates is often used to approximate the relationship between EMC, temperature (''T''), and relative humidity (''h''):<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hailwood |first= A.J.|author2=S. Horrobin |year=1946 |title=Absorption of water by polymers: analysis in terms of a simple model |journal=Trans. Faraday Soc. |volume=42B |issue= |pages=84–102 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Rasmussen | first = E.F. | editor = Forest Products Laboratory, U.S. Department of Agriculture. | title = Dry Kiln Operators Manual | publisher = Hardwood Research Council | year = 1988}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Eleotério |first=Jackson Roberto |author2=Clóvis Roberto Haselein |author3=Nestor Pedro Giacomini |title = A Program to Estimate the Equilibrium Moisture Content of Wood |journal=Ciência Florestal |volume=8 |issue=1 |pages=13–22 | url = http://www.ufsm.br/cienciaflorestal/artigos/v8n1/art2v8n1.pdf |ISSN = 0103-9954|accessdate=2008-11-14 }}</ref>
:<math>M_{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{1800}{W}\left[\frac{kh}{1-kh}\,+\,\frac{k_1kh+2k_1k_2k^2h^2}{1+k_1kh+k_1k_2k^2h^2}\right]</math>
where ''M''<sub>eq</sub> is the equilibrium moisture content (percent), ''T'' is the temperature (degrees Fahrenheit), h is the relative humidity (fractional) and:
:<math>W = 330 + 0.452\,T + 0.00415\,T^2 </math> :<math>k = 0.791 + 4.63\times 10^{-4}\,T - 8.44\times 10^{-7}\,T^2 </math> :<math>k_1= 6.34 + 7.75\times 10^{-4}\,T - 9.35\times 10^{-5}\,T^2 </math> :<math>k_2= 1.09 + 2.84\times 10^{-2}\,T - 9.04\times 10^{-5}\,T^2 </math>
This equation does not account for the slight variations with wood species, state of mechanical stress, and/or [[hysteresis]]. It is an empirical fit to tabulated data provided in the same reference, and closely agrees with the tabulated data. For example, at T=140 deg F, h=0.55, EMC=8.4% from the above equation, while EMC=8.0% from the tabulated data.
== Equilibrium moisture content of sands, soils and building materials == Materials such as stones, sand and ceramics are considered 'dry' and have much lower equilibrium moisture content than organic material like wood and leather. <ref>Leivo, Virpi & Rantala, Jukka. (2003). Moisture Behavior of Slab-On-Ground Structures</ref> typically a fraction of a percent by weight when in equilibrium of air of [[Relative humidity]] 10% to 90%. This affects the rate that buildings need to dry out after construction, typical cements starting with 40-60% water content. This is also important for construction materials such as render reinforced with organic materials, as modest changes in content of different types of straw and wood shavings have a significant influence on the overall moisture content<ref>An experimental investigation on equilibrium moisture content of earth plasters with natural reinforcement fibres for straw bale buildings Taha Ashour, Heiko Georg , Wei Wu </ref>

[[File:1953 Fender Champ model 5C1.jpg|thumb|1953 Fender Champ in tweed covering]]
The '''Fender Champ''' was a [[guitar amplifier]] made by [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]]. It was introduced in 1948 and discontinued in 1982.<ref>Teagle, J. and Sprung, J.: Fender Amps: The First Fifty Years</ref> An updated version was introduced in 2006 as part of the "Vintage Modified" line.
The Champ had the lowest power output and the simplest circuit for all of the Fender [[Vacuum tube amplifier|tube amps]]. The Champ had only one power tube, and the power stage circuit is, typically, [[Single-ended signalling|single-ended]] and [[Class-A amplifier|class A]]. Five [[watt]]s and the simple toneful circuit allowed the Champ to be used easily and often in recording studios.
== Champion 800/600 == First introduced in 1948, it sported the name "Champion 800"<ref>{{cite web|last=Isadore |first=Jason |url=http://myfenderchamp.com/2010/08/04/fender-champion-800-serial-number-591/ |title=Champion 800 |publisher=Myfenderchamp.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> (with 8" speaker), changing a year later to "Champion 600" (6" speaker) with circuit designation 5B1. It was rated at about 3 watts, featuring a "T.V. Front" style cabinet; the 800 was covered in greenish fabric while the 600 featured two-tone blonde and brown vinyl covering. This style lasted until 1953, when Fender's cabinet style changed to the "Wide Panel" design with a [[Tweed (Fender)|tweed cloth covering]]. Fender also renamed the circuit the "5C1", "5" standing for the decade (1950s), "C" for the third circuit revision, and "1" was the Champ's circuit designation. The 5C1<ref>{{cite web|last=Isadore |first=Jason |url=http://myfenderchamp.com/2010/03/11/fender-champ-5c1-wiring-diagram/ |title=5C1 circuit |publisher=Myfenderchamp.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> circuit was extraordinarily simple, using one 6SJ7 pentode in the preamplifier section to provide a single stage of voltage amplification, one 6V6 beam power tetrode in the power amplifier section, a 5Y3 rectifier tube and a single volume knob with no tone controls.
==The Champ== By 1955 Fender started putting its amps in the "Narrow Panel" tweed cabinet with a plastic oxblood color grill cloth,<ref>{{cite web|last=Isadore |first=Jason |url=http://myfenderchamp.com/2009/09/12/grill-cloth/ |title=1959 Tweed Fender Champ Grill Cloth | My Fender Champ | Vintage Amps |publisher=My Fender Champ |date= |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> and by this time the Champ was officially named the Champ (model 5E1). Through 1957, Champs only had a six-inch speaker, but the 1958 model 5F1 featured an 8". The 5E1<ref>{{cite web|last=Isadore |first=Jason |url=http://myfenderchamp.com/2010/03/17/fender-champ-5e1-wiring-diagram/ |title=5E1 |publisher=Myfenderchamp.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> and 5F1<ref>{{cite web|last=Isadore |first=Jason |url=http://myfenderchamp.com/2010/03/29/fender-champ-5f1-wiring-diagram/ |title=5F1 |publisher=Myfenderchamp.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> circuits used a [[12AX7]] dual triode in the preamplifier to provide two stages of voltage amplification, and a single 6V6GT power tube to produce about 5 watts. A Champ from this era can easily be dated by the code stamped on the tube chart,<ref>{{cite web|last=Isadore |first=Jason |url=http://myfenderchamp.com/2009/08/29/how-to-date-a-fender-tweed-champ/ |title=How to Date a Tweed Fender Champ Amplifier by the Tube Chart | My Fender Champ | Vintage Amps |publisher=My Fender Champ |date= |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> by the code stamped on the speaker<ref>{{cite web|last=Isadore |first=Jason |url=http://myfenderchamp.com/2009/10/13/how-to-date-a-tweed-fender-champ-amplifier-by-the-speaker-code/ |title=How to Date a Tweed Fender Champ Amplifier by the Speaker Code | My Fender Champ | Vintage Amps |publisher=My Fender Champ |date= |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> or by its serial number.<ref>{{cite web|last=Isadore |first=Jason |url=http://myfenderchamp.com/2009/10/26/how-to-date-a-tweed-fender-champ-by-serial-number/ |title=How to Date a Tweed Fender Champ Amplifier by Serial Number | My Fender Champ | Vintage Amps |publisher=My Fender Champ |date=2009-12-01 |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref>
==Blackface/Silverface== The 5F1 lasted until 1964, when the Champ finally made the transition to the "Blackface" style of circuit and cabinet. A small number of the last 5F1 style cabinets were covered with the "Blackface" amp cosmetics around this transition,<ref>{{cite web|last=Isadore |first=Jason |url=http://myfenderchamp.com/2009/12/06/transition-fender-champ-c-22845/ |title=transition |publisher=Myfenderchamp.com |date=2010-07-20 |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> as the factory most likely ran out of the tweed cloth covering. In 1964, a Champ with tremolo was also introduced. It was called the [[Fender Vibro Champ|Vibro Champ]]. The Champ switched from [[Blackface (Fender)|Blackface]] to [[Silverface]] four years later. Fender brought back the blackface cosmetics for a short time in 1981 before discontinuing the Champ the following year.
==Champion 600 reissue== In 2006, Fender "reissued" the Champion 600. Cosmetically similar to the original Champion 600,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://myfenderchamp.com/category/champion-600/ |title=Champion 600 |publisher=Myfenderchamp.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> internally it features a modified blackface Champ circuit (with the settings of the [[tone stack]] being hard-wired rather than adjustable via Treble and Bass controls, and a couple of additional resistors reducing input-stage gain) and a switch to solid-state rectification from the original [[5Y3]] tube. The current look is the TV-front with two-tone tolex and speaker grille cloth of imitation suede. For a time after Fender's takeover of [[Gretsch]], the same electronics were available with a different look and feel – based on "tweed" Fender amps, despite the branding – as the [[Gretsch]] G5222 Electromatic. Production of the Champion 600 reissue ceased in 2010 and was reintroduced by Fender in late 2014. As of 2016, the Champion 600 was once again discontinued.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.andertons.co.uk/p/2330104900/combo-amps/fender-champion-600-amp |title=Fender Champion 600 Amp |publisher=Andertons.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-12-05}}</ref>
===Specifications=== * Available as a 6" Combo, features an internal 4 ohm speaker output jack * 5 watt RMS * Volume control * Power switch * 2 Input (high, low), 1 Channel * 1× [[12AX7]] and 1× [[6V6]] * Solid-state diode-rectified * Class A, single-ended * Made in China
==Vibro Champ== The '''Fender Vibro Champ''' was a [[guitar amplifier]] made by [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]]. It was first introduced in 1964 and discontinued in 1982. The Vibro Champ featured built-in tremolo with controls for speed and intensity. The [[silverface]] version served as a basis for the [[Fender Bronco Amp|Bronco]] student amplifier of 1967.<ref>Fender Amps:The First 50 Years</ref>
==Vibro Champ XD== In 2007, Fender reintroduced the Vibro Champ as the '''Vibro Champ XD''', part of their "Vintage Modified" series. Aesthetically, the XD is based on the Champ from the [[Blackface (Fender)|blackface]] era. Unlike the Champion 600, which has a strictly all-tube audio signal path, the Vibro Champ XD's tube circuitry is complemented by a [[digital signal processor]] (DSP) that functions as a pre-amp by modelling 16 different amplifiers. The effect of the volume, gain and tone control knobs varies according to the selected amp model. The digitally modelled signal is fed into a class-A single-ended tube circuit, with a [[12AX7]] output tube driver, and a 6V6 output tube. The amp also comes equipped with DSP effects, including reverb, delay, chorus, tremolo, and Vibratone (there is no spring reverb tank).
===Specifications=== * Available as an 8" combo * 5 watt RMS class-A, single-ended * Controls: gain, volume, voicing, treble, bass, FX level, FX select * 1 input, 1 channel * 1 4 ohm speaker output, 1 line-level output (back panel) * 1× 12AX7 and 1× 6V6 * Solid-state diode-rectified * DSP provides 16 effects settings, including chorus, delay, tremolo, reverb, and Vibratone * Made in China
==Super Champ== In 1982, in order to combat its decreasing amp sales, which at that time was around 10,000 units per year, Fender hired Paul Rivera (of [[Rivera Amplifiers]]) and asked him to help design amplifiers with a modern sound. Even though he did not personally create the new designs his direction of the engineering team, headed by Mark Wentling, resulted in some legendary amps. The result included the Super Champ, featuring a 10" speaker and new circuitry, including spring reverb, master volume, a switchable extra gain stage for a 'lead' effect, and a mid boost switch.<ref name="autogenerated69">Teagle, J. and Sprung, J.: ''Fender Amps: The First Fifty Years'', p.69</ref> In order to increase gain and cut costs, the Super Champ utilized 1× 12AX7 for the first and second stage preamp, a 1× 12AT7 for spring reverb driver tube, while a triple-triode 6C10 [[compactron]] is used for three functions; one as a third stage preamp for even more gain, one as the phase inverter (instead of two for most class-AB circuits), and one as recovery for the spring reverb. When the volume knob is pulled, some signal from the 12AT7 reverb driver is re-routed, resulting in higher gain. An optional two-button footswitch allowed for gain switching and reverb on/off. Two 6V6 power tubes provide it with 18 RMS watts. The cabinet was finished in black Tolex, with a black control panel and silver grille cloth. A more expensive version was available, factory-fitted with a Fender-branded EV Force 10 speaker instead of the usual Fender Blue Label. The Super Champ was sold until 1986.
===Specifications=== * Available as a 10" combo, features an internal 8 ohm speaker; some with output jack, some hardwired * 18 watt RMS * Controls: volume (pull for lead), treble (pull for mid boost), bass, reverb, lead level, master. * 1-input, 2-channel * 1× [[12AX7|7025]], 1× [[12AT7]], 1× [[6C10]] Triple triode and 2× [[6V6]] * Solid-state diode rectified * Accutronics 3-spring reverb * Class AB, push–pull
==Champ II== Introduced along with the Super Champ described above, the Champ II was the most basic of the tube amps in the "Rivera-era" range of Fenders, having no reverb or extra gain switching.<ref name="autogenerated69"/> It was discontinued in 1983, along with the Bassman 20 (with which it shared the same metal chassis design), three years before the rest of the range, perhaps because its dearth of features was unfashionable at the time. It had the same colour scheme, power supply, output stage and stock speaker as the Super Champ but the preamp and phase inverter consisted of two 12AX7 tubes.
===Specifications=== * Available as a 10" combo, features an internal 8 ohm speaker output jack * 18 watt RMS * Controls: volume, treble (pull for mid boost), bass, master. * 1 input * 2× [[12AX7|7025]], 2× [[6V6]] * Solid-state diode-rectified * Class AB, push–pull
==Super Champ XD== {{Unreferenced section|date=February 2008}} In 2007, Fender resurrected the Super Champ name with the '''Super Champ XD''', part of their "Vintage Modified" series. The look is based on the blackface model. Although for a limited period of time a special edition Blonde version was produced, Fender’s Consumer Relations Department states that the blonde special edition Super Champ XD with oxblood grill was a FSR (factory special run) that was limited to only 1,000 produced. The blonde version is no longer available new and Fender has completed the amps' production run so no more will be produced or available from Fender. Unlike the Champion 600 (all tube circuitry), the Super Champ XD (like the Vibro Champ XD) is a hybrid (tube circuitry complemented with digital modeling and effects). Aside from one dual-triode 12AX7 and two 6V6 output tubes, it also has a [[digital signal processor]] (DSP) which models 16 different amplifiers and programs the volume, gain, and tone controls accordingly.
It has two channels, channel 1 being a clean channel, and channel 2 having both clean and distortion voices, using modeling technology to provide 15 additional voices. Both the Bass/Treble EQ and Effects (FX) are global settings meaning they affect the sound of both channel 1 and channel 2.
There are two stages of amplification: the first stage is done by solid-state op amps and the DSP,{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} which also provide the desired voicing of the amps. It is then fed into the first triode of the 12AX7, which acts as a second stage preamp, provides the additional tube gain for both channels and acts as an interface between the solid-state circuitry and the tube circuitry. The second triode is a phase inverter, which creates mirror images of the signal to drive the output tubes. This arrangement provides the same feel of a complete tube amp while allowing multiple voicing. The DSP chip also provides effects, including reverb, delay, chorus, and tremolo. There is no spring reverb tank.
In 2012, Fender released the '''Super Champ X2''', a redesign of the XD. The X2 is designed to interface with the FUSE software used by the Fender Mustang series of modeling solid-state amplifiers, and is also available in both combo and discrete head/speaker cabinet units.
===Specifications=== * Available as a 10" Combo, features an internal 8 ohm speaker output jack * 15 watt RMS * Controls: volume 1, channel select, gain, volume 2, voicing, treble, bass, FX level, FX select * 1-input, 2-channel (clean and voicing) * 1× [[12AX7]] and 2× [[6V6]] * Solid-state diode-rectified * Class AB, push–pull
==Fender '57 Champ== Fender reissued the 1957 narrow panel tweed Champ in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url= |title=Fender '57 Champ Amp Review|publisher=[[Premier Guitar]]|date=17 December 2009 |accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref>
==Models== *Champion "800" (1948–1949) – First version of the Champ. *Champion "600" (1949–1955, 2006–2013) – Replaced the Champion "800", modified/reissued in 2006 *Vibro Champ (1964–1982; 2007–2012) – A Champ with tremolo; reissued in 2007 as the Vibro Champ XD, with hybrid (tube/solid-state) circuit, and utilization of DSP for 16 effects and voicings *Eric Clapton Signature Vibro Champ (2013–present) – Based on the original Vibro Champ with single volume and tremolo controls in a tweed cabinet; it has custom-made Schumacher transformers and an 8" Weber speaker<ref>{{cite news|last1=Childs|first1=Zac|title="God"-Approved?: Fender's EC Twinolux and Vibro Champ|newspaper=[[Vintage Guitar (magazine)|Vintage Guitar]]|pages=138–39|accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref> *Champ II (1982–1983) – 18 watts/10" speaker. *Super Champ (1982–1985; 2007–Present) – channel switching and reverb; reissued in 2007 as the Super Champ XD with hybrid (tube/solid-state) circuit, and utilization of DSP for 16 effects and voicings, and later as the X2 with an added [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] connection for computer accessible modeling *Champ 12 (1987–1992) – 12 watts/12" speaker *Champ 25/25SE (1992–1994) – tube/solid-state amp
==References== {{reflist|2}}
